Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: CAREER: High-Resolution X-ray Spectroscopic Studies of Base Metal Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Kyle M. Lancaster of the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology at Cornell University to use cutting-edge X-ray spectroscopies to explore the reactivity of earth-abundant transition metal catalysts. The goal of this research is to determine the mechanisms by which these catalysts effect remarkable chemical transformations including the breakdown of biomass to simple sugars for biofuels and the conversion of natural gas to transportable liquid forms. Understanding the reactivity of catalysts incorporating earth-abundant metals is key to a sustainable chemical future. The proposed work incorporates elements of biochemistry, synthesis, spectroscopy, and theory, affording interdisciplinary training for undergraduate and graduate researchers. The interaction between light and matter that forms the basis of spectroscopy is the foundation for outreach efforts under this project; specifically, hands-on "lab kits" are to be developed for K-12 students to explore properties of light.

Valence-to-core X-ray emission spectroscopy, high-energy-resolution fluorescence-detected X-ray absorption spectroscopy and resonant inelastic X-ray scattering are emerging, versatile methods to characterize coordination environments and ligand electronic structures. These methods are being used to probe copper catalysts, defined here as either enzymes or coordination complexes. One such catalyst to be studied is a mononuclear copper enzyme that oxidatively cleaves polysaccharides in biomass such as chitin and cellulose. Stopped-flow kinetics and rapid freeze quench methods are being used to trap reactive copper-oxygen species for X-ray spectroscopic characterization. Nature's copper catalyst for conversion of methane to methanol is a focus of this study. This catalyst is an integral membrane protein whose reactive copper-oxygen species have eluded study by conventional methods. Efforts are to be extended to an abiotic system: copper-catalyzed aerobic alcohol oxidation. This study could demonstrate that the methods to be employed do not necessarily require precise knowledge of precatalysts in order to characterize reaction constituents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project advanced understanding of how the distribution of electrons within transition metal complexes impact their ability to serve as catalysts or reagents for chemical reactions. Establishing these connections is vital to developing new catalysts using earth-abundant, relatively non-toxic metals like copper and iron. This understanding was achieved by developing and applying X-ray spectroscopy techniques, which are means to probe individual elements within molecule. Specifically, nitrogen K-edge (where the most tightly bound electrons of N are excited to probe the disposition of electrons in nitrogen) and high energy resolution fluroescence detected X-ray absorption (which exposes otherwise "hidden" features in a spectrum) were advanced with support of this grant. Key results included identifying the electronic structure underpinning the reactivity of "green" Cu-aminoxyl systems for selective alcohol oxidation, the definitive identification of a long-hypothesized intermediate––a copper-nitrene––as well as identification of ligand field inversion (where, contrary to convention, the ligand bears electron holes rather than the transition metal) as a common feature of high-valent copper complexes.

Broader Impacts

Replacing costly second- and third-row transition metal catalysts with first-row or "base" metal catalysts is vital to a sustainable chemical industry in the US. A key to effecting this paradigm shift is understanding how the electronic structures of first-row complexes can be manipulated to satisfy the requirements for reactivity. In addition to providing insights that will lead to improved base metal catalysts, this grant also supported education of students from the K-8 level all the way through post-doctoral study. Specifically, three graduate students (including one female student and one hispanic male student) earned Ph.D.s through their contributions to projects supported by this grant. Two additional graduate students contributed to projects supported by this grant. Three postdoctoral researchers (two female) contributed to these efforts. This grant also supported outreach efforts, specifically hands-on demonstrations of the use of photons to probe matter at the Ithaca Sciencenter, a science museum geared toward K-8 students. In addition, our research group contributed a hands-on experiment at the annual Expanding Your Horizons conference which introduces science concepts to elementary school aged female students.
